statement.para: It transforms the vector \Vect{a} := (1,1) into the vector \Mtrx{A}\cdot\Vect{a} = (4,4). This means that \Vect{a} is an eigenvector of \Mtrx{A} with eigenvalue 4, and \Mtrx{A} transforms the line L_1 in the direction of \Vect{a} into itself while stretching it by the factor 4.

Further \Mtrx{A} transforms the vector \Vect{b}:=(-1,1) into the vector \Mtrx{A}\cdot\Vect{b} = (-2,2). This means that \Vect{b} is an eigenvector of \Mtrx{A} with eigenvalue 2, and \Mtrx{A} transforms the line L_2 in the direction of \Vect{b} into itself while stretching it by the factor of 2.
The picture above shows the plane \RNr[2] before and after transformation by \Mtrx{A}.

li.para: The vectors \Vect{a} and \Vect{b} are rendered in green.
The vectors \Mtrx{A}\cdot\Vect{a} and \Mtrx{A}\cdot\Vect{b} are rendered in red. They are scaled by a factor of 4 and 2, respectively.
The circle of radius 1 centered at the origin is rendered in green.
The result of transforming this circle by \Mtrx{A} is the red ellipse.
